post.body:
+general was originally intended to function as the "cesspit" of Ruqqus, holding posts rejected from other Guilds, so that those Guilds could curate their desired content without censoring rejected content.

In keeping with this, we are making two changes to +general. The goal is to encourage users to find and participate in other Guilds.

* Direct submissions have been disabled for +general.
* +general has been removed from All/Trending.
post.body_html:
+general was originally intended to function as the "cesspit" of Ruqqus, holding posts rejected from other Guilds, so that those Guilds could curate their desired content without censoring rejected content.

In keeping with this, we are making two changes to +general. The goal is to encourage users to find and participate in other Guilds.

  • Direct submissions have been disabled for +general.
  • +general has been removed from All/Trending.

body:
**Note:** all of the rest of this aside, the biggest issue is the manner in which it happened. You did it at the request of your discord buddies, and then laughed about it like banning is funny, and you and all of the participants clearly enjoyed your high of power. At least you did it in public, unlike reddit which does so in secret places like DefaultMods instead.

---

You said saying Hitler was the good guy is not permitted on the site. It's not okay, but it doesn't break the rules unless they're specifically calling for genocide (and actually planning on it, not just basement-dwellers who are trolling everyone) and most Nazis deny the Holocaust. And unless the *whole guild* was about that, you only remove the specific offending accounts and posts. Even if guildmasters were doing it, ban their accounts and let the remaining mods or someone else have the guild.

> Also, @CrystalVulpine is willfully ignoring the half dozen or so nazi guilds that aren't banned because they aren't breaking the rules.

Not true, remember JosephGoebbels and others?

At least you did it in public, unlike reddit which does so in secret places like DefaultMods instead.

You said saying Hitler was the good guy is not permitted on the site. It's not okay, but it doesn't break the rules unless they're specifically calling for genocide (and actually planning on it, not just basement-dwellers who are trolling everyone) and most Nazis deny the Holocaust. And unless the whole guild was about that, you only remove the specific offending accounts and posts. Even if guildmasters were doing it, ban their accounts and let the remaining mods or someone else have the guild.

Also, @CrystalVulpine is willfully ignoring the half dozen or so nazi guilds that aren't banned because they aren't breaking the rules.

Not true, remember JosephGoebbels and others?

post.body:
These are the favorite "proof-texts" for messianic Jews and those who insist that believers must follow the laws of the old testament and Jewish torah:

> 17 “Do not think that I came to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I did not come to abolish but to fulfill. 18 For truly I say to you, until heaven and earth pass away, not the smallest letter or stroke shall pass from the Law until all is accomplished. 19 Whoever then annuls one of the least of these commandments, and teaches others to do the same, shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven; but whoever keeps and teaches them, he shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven. 20 For I say to you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will not enter the kingdom of heaven.

>    16“The Law and the Prophets were proclaimed until John; since that time the gospel of the kingdom of God has been preached, and everyone is forcing his way into it. 17“But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one stroke of a letter of the Law to fail.

But considering, like, the entire rest of the book, this makes no sense. A contradictory statement such as this is a sign that it was not written by the original author, but interpolated later by copyists. In the Matthew one, this statement is literally followed by a bunch of attacks on this exact law, where he repeatedly says, "You've heard it said in the law that you should do this, but I'm telling you not to do that, but do this other thing instead". His actions in the rest of all four gospels also do not align with this declaration about the law and he breaks huge tenants of the law.

Also indicating this is how this statement appears in different places in Matthew and Luke, but that is unlikely to have been original given that they used a common source text. "The law and the prophets were proclaimed until John" is also found in Matthew, but the statement about the law doesn't appear there, but in a different location, so it's unlikely that it was in their source gospel. And it would be very hard for both authors to coincidentally conjure up the exact same statement independently. It would make sense, however, for a scribe to find two different places that they think their statement would fit best into the text of each gospel.

Let's see how the Matthean version reads with this text removed:

> 17 “Do not think that I came to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I did not come to abolish but to complete. 20 For I say to you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will not enter the kingdom of heaven.
> 
> 21 “You have heard that the ancients were told...But I say to you...

This version makes **perfect** sense in light of the context. He came to give the true law, to complete it. The Pharisees were not following this law, but the old law to its letter which was corrupted according to Jeremiah 8:8. Verse 20 follows closely after verse 17, and its reasoning contradicts that of verses 18-19 which try to defend the legalism of the Pharisees. They thought they were justified by doing this, but in reality they weren't. It really seems 18-19, and Luke 16:17 too, were inserted by a scribe who felt uncomfortable portraying Jesus as being against the Jewish law. This could be an Ebionite or Jewish scribe hoping to infiltrate or a church father who was worried that people might read the original version as supporting things like Marcionism, and sought to "clarify" it for them (which was extremely common in ancient times).

+general was originally intended to function as the "cesspit" of Ruqqus, holding posts rejected from other Guilds, so that those Guilds could curate their desired content without censoring rejected content.

* +general has been removed from All/Trending.

body: No, I don't believe it's the word of God because otherwise it would have existed before 382 AD and wouldn't be full of forgeries, mistakes, and contradictions (which the book admits implicitly in a good many places, and explicitly in Jeremiah 8:8). It was compiled by the church, and specifically the Catholic church. Yes, indeed they are our only authority for claiming the Bible is the "word of God", as the book itself actually warns against this (all that talk about "the law is good but doesn't justify and isn't perfect" was made at a time before the new testament existed, meaning that law was all they had). Prior to that the only sect with any kind of bible was Marcionism, and the church arguable made their own to compete with it. Even afterwards, the orthodox church and other sects took much longer to adopt a canon of scripture, and to this day they differ. And the protestant bible which you are probably referring to didn't exist until Martin Luther, who first arranged it, and he himself would agree with me seeing how he also had his doubts about James, Jude, Ruth, and Revelation.

body:
> When you deny the authority of The Bible, you give yourself authority to determine what is God's word.

That argument doesn't hold water, because you still determined that the Bible is this word. You're just repeating talking points on reflex. The Bible is still under your authority, because it is so large that you can just pick the parts you like and find a clever way to ignore or reinterpret the parts that contradict those ones.

> All the doubts you have concerning forgeries, mistakes, and contradictions were provided to you by Satan, so you would reject the bible.

Or perhaps he decided to trick people by inserting errors into a holy text that people have more faith in than they do the God they supposedly worship.

Wrong. If there is an infallible text anywhere, it isn't the bible, an even less likely an arrangement of it that didn't exist until the 14th century. I know of no such text, nor do I think the word of God can be fit into words. The good guys in the bible communicated with God directly and others criticized them for breaking the rules and not bowing down to whatever religious institution was impersonating for God at the time. There are accounts in many of the prophets of the Israelites perverting the law and the scriptures and changing them to their liking, which is why the old testament is so barbaric and supports pagan ideas like sacrifices and legalism and prosperity gospel. It is also clear that earlier writers did not know the torah which was supposedly given by Moses, and even the later ones didn't have it in any form we'd recognize today until Ezra-Nehemiah, characters who were paranoid about the "holy race" being tainted by goyim and are testified by many sources as being the final redactors of the old testament, which is implied even in their own book. Of course your pastor or radio show host will never let you see this, and if they do they'll find some way to twist it into meaning the opposite of what it actually says.

> I'm not trying to overload you with scripture, just want you to have all of it. God speaks about how his words are pure, and unchanging, and kept completely preserved for all generations.

You are trying to prove that the Bible is infallible using statements about "God's words" which I already established is not the Bible. Not to mention that this is circular logic; the few books that do claim infallibility (the torah, revelation) are exactly the ones which are unlikely to be authentic, and even then only make that claim about themselves, not other books.

> So them changing certain words, or excluding books or including ones that aren't scripture, this does not match the promises to us that God has made.

The only way you can think this is if someone else just told you and you accepted it without question. Stop being so trusting of other people, including the ones who call themselves believers. There are hundreds of thousands of differences in biblical manuscripts, many of them significant, and that's just the beginning as the majority of the editing would've occurred prior to all our manuscript evidence. That's for the *new* testament, which only had about 2-300 years between composition and our first manuscripts. Imagine the old testament after almost 3,000 years and *at least* two major redactions. The protestant bible you know of didn't exist until Luther. The bible itself didn't exist until 382 AD, and even then canons were wildly different across denominations (and yes, those existed back then, and a lot of things we would immediately consider heresy now were legitimate controversies in those days). God never promised an inerrant text about anything; only men.

> And this promise is for all generations, so certain time periods where we didn't have the books or weren't' aware of them is not possible.

Your own argument betrays you, because there was who knows how long before the time of Moses, probably a lot longer than has passed since then, when not a single book of the Bible had been written yet. How did those people find God?

> We would not have to figure the bible out on our own, and not have access to all the books or the proper translations or the original meanings. God has the power to provide this to us and he has said that he has. Satan however can cast doubt on the King James Bible, cause people to question the translations, or put more faith in other translations or the supposed Greek and Hebrew source texts he has forged or perverted over the years,

Until now I was arguing as if you were referring to the original texts. But this is even more foolish of a notion. You first claim that God has always provided the Bible, then claim that the only authentic Bible is a version not produced until 400 years ago. Tell me, when did God ever specifically sanction the King James Bible? The answer is he didn't, and that it is merely a translation produced in 1611, only in Jacobean English we can barely read today, and with much less scholarly knowledge to make informed decisions. And what do you think its sources were? The very same Greek and Hebrew source texts you attack, only much later and slightly more corrupted ones. So since God never told you that the King James Bible is perfect, then by what authority do you make such a claim? What others have told you? Don't be so trusting.

> but that doesn't change that The King James has been preserved the past 400 years for us and hasn't changed.

Actually it has: the apocrypha has been removed, an update was made in the 18th century, and several very wild printing errors have been fixed. That said, it's much easier for a text produced in the early days of the information age, when printing existed, and recent enough to still have the original copy of it, to remain as it is than in the days when paper and ink were expensive, the church oversaw everything, and everything was handcopied, and editing a text you were copying was not usually regarded as wrong.

> You might think the men that wrote the King James were corrupt or using it to manipulate the people, there is history that says otherwise, but ultimately that would be a spiritual decision on your part. For every critique thrown at it, there is always an explanation. Or maybe there are books in the 66 you doubt?

The original King James Bible contains 80 books, not 66. So since you yourself doubt books 14 books, who are you to judge me for also doubting certain books?

> Throwing out Paul's teachings is common amongst Christians today, but he is the apostle to the gentiles and Jesus did appear to him.

It was actually more common in ancient times. Christians today elevate Paul over Jesus, mostly ignoring the gospels and studying mainly Paul's letters and the other epistles supposedly written by "apostles", with a bit of Torah mixed in. In ancient times you had several sects that went as far as denouncing Paul as an apostate. The catholic church did not agree, but tended to avoid Paul in the early days, not so much because of anything about Paul, but because many heretics were so fanatic about him and they didn't want to become associated with them. Paul, as far as I can tell, was a legitimate evangelist in the first century, and his letters are good, but he is not infallible and his writings are heavily redacted to conform with church doctrine. This does not include 1 Timothy and Titus which are undoubtedly forgeries preaching evil doctrines and usually at odds with authentic Paul; it is very obvious from their contents that they were written to "prove" the authority of the church.

I do not have time to individually refute every single quote of yours, but not one of them references any kind of Bible. Most of them, when read in context, are clearly about something else, including the most famous "purified seven times" which is actually about keeping promises: God is true to his word. Only a few make specific claims about the words of a book, and they are unsurprisingly from books that are probably forgeries, because that is exactly what you would expect a forger to put in his fake book, to paraphrase Martin Luther.

> God has the power to provide you his complete world, it's just a matter of if you believe he has done this for you.

He has, and it is not the Bible.

When you deny the authority of The Bible, you give yourself authority to determine what is God's word.

That argument doesn't hold water, because you still determined that the Bible is this word. You're just repeating talking points on reflex. The Bible is still under your authority, because it is so large that you can just pick the parts you like and find a clever way to ignore or reinterpret the parts that contradict those ones.

All the doubts you have concerning forgeries, mistakes, and contradictions were provided to you by Satan, so you would reject the bible.

Or perhaps he decided to trick people by inserting errors into a holy text that people have more faith in than they do the God they supposedly worship.

Wrong. If there is an infallible text anywhere, it isn't the bible, an even less likely an arrangement of it that didn't exist until the 14th century. I know of no such text, nor do I think the word of God can be fit into words. The good guys in the bible communicated with God directly and others criticized them for breaking the rules and not bowing down to whatever religious institution was impersonating for God at the time. There are accounts in many of the prophets of the Israelites perverting the law and the scriptures and changing them to their liking, which is why the old testament is so barbaric and supports pagan ideas like sacrifices and legalism and prosperity gospel. It is also clear that earlier writers did not know the torah which was supposedly given by Moses, and even the later ones didn't have it in any form we'd recognize today until Ezra-Nehemiah, characters who were paranoid about the "holy race" being tainted by goyim and are testified by many sources as being the final redactors of the old testament, which is implied even in their own book. Of course your pastor or radio show host will never let you see this, and if they do they'll find some way to twist it into meaning the opposite of what it actually says.

I'm not trying to overload you with scripture, just want you to have all of it. God speaks about how his words are pure, and unchanging, and kept completely preserved for all generations.

You are trying to prove that the Bible is infallible using statements about "God's words" which I already established is not the Bible. Not to mention that this is circular logic; the few books that do claim infallibility (the torah, revelation) are exactly the ones which are unlikely to be authentic, and even then only make that claim about themselves, not other books.

So them changing certain words, or excluding books or including ones that aren't scripture, this does not match the promises to us that God has made.

The only way you can think this is if someone else just told you and you accepted it without question. Stop being so trusting of other people, including the ones who call themselves believers. There are hundreds of thousands of differences in biblical manuscripts, many of them significant, and that's just the beginning as the majority of the editing would've occurred prior to all our manuscript evidence. That's for the new testament, which only had about 2-300 years between composition and our first manuscripts. Imagine the old testament after almost 3,000 years and at least two major redactions. The protestant bible you know of didn't exist until Luther. The bible itself didn't exist until 382 AD, and even then canons were wildly different across denominations (and yes, those existed back then, and a lot of things we would immediately consider heresy now were legitimate controversies in those days). God never promised an inerrant text about anything; only men.

And this promise is for all generations, so certain time periods where we didn't have the books or weren't' aware of them is not possible.

Your own argument betrays you, because there was who knows how long before the time of Moses, probably a lot longer than has passed since then, when not a single book of the Bible had been written yet. How did those people find God?

We would not have to figure the bible out on our own, and not have access to all the books or the proper translations or the original meanings. God has the power to provide this to us and he has said that he has. Satan however can cast doubt on the King James Bible, cause people to question the translations, or put more faith in other translations or the supposed Greek and Hebrew source texts he has forged or perverted over the years,

Until now I was arguing as if you were referring to the original texts. But this is even more foolish of a notion. You first claim that God has always provided the Bible, then claim that the only authentic Bible is a version not produced until 400 years ago. Tell me, when did God ever specifically sanction the King James Bible? The answer is he didn't, and that it is merely a translation produced in 1611, only in Jacobean English we can barely read today, and with much less scholarly knowledge to make informed decisions. And what do you think its sources were? The very same Greek and Hebrew source texts you attack, only much later and slightly more corrupted ones. So since God never told you that the King James Bible is perfect, then by what authority do you make such a claim? What others have told you? Don't be so trusting.

but that doesn't change that The King James has been preserved the past 400 years for us and hasn't changed.

Actually it has: the apocrypha has been removed, an update was made in the 18th century, and several very wild printing errors have been fixed. That said, it's much easier for a text produced in the early days of the information age, when printing existed, and recent enough to still have the original copy of it, to remain as it is than in the days when paper and ink were expensive, the church oversaw everything, and everything was handcopied, and editing a text you were copying was not usually regarded as wrong.

You might think the men that wrote the King James were corrupt or using it to manipulate the people, there is history that says otherwise, but ultimately that would be a spiritual decision on your part. For every critique thrown at it, there is always an explanation. Or maybe there are books in the 66 you doubt?

The original King James Bible contains 80 books, not 66. So since you yourself doubt books 14 books, who are you to judge me for also doubting certain books?

Throwing out Paul's teachings is common amongst Christians today, but he is the apostle to the gentiles and Jesus did appear to him.

It was actually more common in ancient times. Christians today elevate Paul over Jesus, mostly ignoring the gospels and studying mainly Paul's letters and the other epistles supposedly written by "apostles", with a bit of Torah mixed in. In ancient times you had several sects that went as far as denouncing Paul as an apostate. The catholic church did not agree, but tended to avoid Paul in the early days, not so much because of anything about Paul, but because many heretics were so fanatic about him and they didn't want to become associated with them. Paul, as far as I can tell, was a legitimate evangelist in the first century, and his letters are good, but he is not infallible and his writings are heavily redacted to conform with church doctrine. This does not include 1 Timothy and Titus which are undoubtedly forgeries preaching evil doctrines and usually at odds with authentic Paul; it is very obvious from their contents that they were written to "prove" the authority of the church.

I do not have time to individually refute every single quote of yours, but not one of them references any kind of Bible. Most of them, when read in context, are clearly about something else, including the most famous "purified seven times" which is actually about keeping promises: God is true to his word. Only a few make specific claims about the words of a book, and they are unsurprisingly from books that are probably forgeries, because that is exactly what you would expect a forger to put in his fake book, to paraphrase Martin Luther.

God has the power to provide you his complete world, it's just a matter of if you believe he has done this for you.

He has, and it is not the Bible.

Throwing out Paul's teachings is common amongst Christians today, but he is the apostle to the gentiles and Jesus did appear to him.

"If thou wilt not observe to do all the words of this law that are written in this book, that thou mayest fear this glorious and fearful name, THE LORD THY GOD; Then the LORD will make thy plagues wonderful, and the plagues of thy seed, even great plagues, and of long continuance, and sore sicknesses." (Deuteronomy 28:58-59)

"I will worship toward thy holy temple, and praise thy name for thy lovingkindness and for thy truth: for thou hast magnified thy word above all thy name." (Ps 138:2)

"Every word of God is pure: he is a shield unto them that put their trust in him. Add thou not unto his words, lest he reprove thee, and thou be found a liar." (Proverbs 30:5-6)

"Ye shall not add unto the word which I command you, neither shall ye diminish ought from it, that ye may keep the commandments of the LORD your God which I command you." (Deuteronomy 4:2)

"For I testify unto every man that heareth the words of the prophecy of this book, If any man shall add unto these things, God shall add unto him the plagues that are written in this book: And if any man shall take away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away his part out of the book of life, and out of the holy city, and from the things which are written in this book." (Rev. 22:18-19)

**The Word of God Lives and Endures Forever **

1 Peter 1:23 "Being born again, not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible, by the word of God which liveth and abideth forever."

Psalm 12:6-7 "The words of the Lord are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times. Thou shalt keep them, O Lord, thou shalt preserve them from this generation forever."

Ps. 111:7-8 "The works of his hands are verity and judgment; all his commandments are sure. They stand fast for ever and ever, and are done in truth and uprightness."

Is. 40:8 "The grass withereth, the flower fadeth: but the word of our God shall stand for ever."

Ps. 117:2 "... the truth of the Lord endureth for ever. Praise ye the Lord."

Ps. 119:152 "Concerning thy testimonies, I have known of old that thou hast founded them for ever."

Ps 119:160 "Thy word is true from the beginning: and every one of thy righteous judgments endureth for ever."

**Each Word Forever ** Matthew 24:35 "Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away."

Psalm 12:6-7 "The words of the Lord are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times. Thou shalt keep them, O Lord, thou shalt preserve them from this generation forever."

1 Peter 1:23 "Being born again, not of corruptible seed, but of incorruptible, by the word of God which liveth and abideth forever."

HIS WORD HAS BEEN KEPT AVAILABLE TO EACH AND EVERY GENERATION

Psalm 33:11 "The counsel of the Lord standeth forever, the thoughts of his heart to all generations."

Psalm 100:5 "For the Lord is good; his mercy is everlasting; and his truth endureth to all generations."

Ps 119:89-90 "For ever, O LORD, thy word is settled in heaven. Thy faithfulness is unto all generations: thou hast established the earth, and it abideth."

Isaiah 59:21 "As for me this is my covenant with them, saith the Lord; My spirit that is upon thee, and my words which I have put in thy mouth, shall not pass out of the thy mouth, nor out of the mouth of thy seed, nor out of the mouth of thy seed's seed saith the Lord, from henceforth and forever."

Anyway, I understand how you feel and why you believe what you do because I've been there myself. But please know that God ensured you would have his perfect and complete word. That is important for Him to do and it's within his power to do so.

Let's not continue to disagree about this, you will never change my mind, and I just hope that what I have said here stays with you and maybe in the future you can reconsider. God has the power to provide you his complete world, it's just a matter of if you believe he has done this for you.

body:
You might want to consider moving away from church and organized religion; it was actually one of the things the people in the new testament had major conflicts with. You probably feel intense anxiety because at most religious places there is an implicit expectation to mask yourself and conform to the group, else they'll shun you. This isn't Christian behavior but it's so ingrained in human nature that's it's nearly impossible to find a place that doesn't do this, and unfortunately religion can make it worse because it tends to create a culture of moral superiority and virtue signaling.

> f
> 
> “I never realized you were autistic I just thought you were kinda quirky or weird”

This happens a lot and it's probably the real reason 4x as many more men are diagnosed. The social norms for women are typically much broader than they are for men, so they blend in and are perceived as normal while men with autism stick out like a sore thumb. It's a bit strange but not exactly abnormal for a girl to stay shay and childish into adulthood, but when it's a teenage boy who's still obsessed with independent play and clinging to stuffed animals it's clear that he can't or won't follow social norms. Unfortunately the reverse is true for anxiety and depression as men are expected to mask all their problems, do all the hard stuff, and never complain, plus the natural biological state of a man is unfortunately comparable to that of a depressed or stressed woman, so again it's just "normal".

You change your beliefs based on *your interpretation* of the Bible, and even if it were 100% objective it is still your authority because you decided to shift that authority to the Biblical text. If God had made a statement specifying the books of the bible and that they are inerrant it would be different, but he has not. There's no way around it, you're simply relying on what people have told you.

> What is your complete word that is not the bible?

I'll let John chapter 1 answer that for you.

What is your complete word that is not the bible?

He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
> Paul is the apostle to the gentiles and jews during the dispensation of Grace (which we live in).

There are no dispensations and Paul is not "the" apostle to the gentiles, he is only one of them, of which they are many.

> Seems like you want to reject that and instead build your doctrine around the Gospel of the Kingdom, which Jesus preached to the Jews. This gospel is not yours, nor for Jews living today.

It seems like you want to make things up to ignore Jesus because Paul is easier to twist and suffers more textual corruption.

> Dispensationalism may solve many of your issues with the supposed contradictions in the bible. After The jews stoned stephen, Jesus appeared to Paul and brought the Gospel of Grace. God will return to the Jews and the Gospel of the Kingdom once this dispensation of Grace has concluded.

There is no concept of dispensationalism at all in any bible I'm aware of. That was popularized by Scofield's notes. Paul isn't aware of it either, he preaches the same gospel to both Jews and gentiles.

> Isaiah has 66 chapters any many if not all correspond to the 66 books. Idk if that can help your disbelief but it was worth trying.

Isaiah was originally 39 chapters, the rest is by 2 anonymous prophets who appended their work to Isaiah instead of authoring their own. Perhaps they worked closely with or were students of Isaiah and felt that would be more appropriate (common in ancient times). The chapters don't correspond with the books, having 66 chapters and 66 books of the protestant bible is a completely normal coincidence.

Paul is the apostle to the gentiles and jews during the dispensation of Grace (which we live in).

There are no dispensations and Paul is not "the" apostle to the gentiles, he is only one of them, of which they are many.

Seems like you want to reject that and instead build your doctrine around the Gospel of the Kingdom, which Jesus preached to the Jews. This gospel is not yours, nor for Jews living today.

It seems like you want to make things up to ignore Jesus because Paul is easier to twist and suffers more textual corruption.

Dispensationalism may solve many of your issues with the supposed contradictions in the bible. After The jews stoned stephen, Jesus appeared to Paul and brought the Gospel of Grace. God will return to the Jews and the Gospel of the Kingdom once this dispensation of Grace has concluded.

There is no concept of dispensationalism at all in any bible I'm aware of. That was popularized by Scofield's notes. Paul isn't aware of it either, he preaches the same gospel to both Jews and gentiles.

Isaiah has 66 chapters any many if not all correspond to the 66 books. Idk if that can help your disbelief but it was worth trying.

Isaiah was originally 39 chapters, the rest is by 2 anonymous prophets who appended their work to Isaiah instead of authoring their own. Perhaps they worked closely with or were students of Isaiah and felt that would be more appropriate (common in ancient times). The chapters don't correspond with the books, having 66 chapters and 66 books of the protestant bible is a completely normal coincidence.

I'm relying on the king james bible.

Paul is the apostle to the gentiles and jews during the dispensation of Grace (which we live in). Seems like you want to reject that and instead build your doctrine around the Gospel of the Kingdom, which Jesus preached to the Jews. This gospel is not yours, nor for Jews living today.

Dispensationalism may solve many of your issues with the supposed contradictions in the bible. After The jews stoned stephen, Jesus appeared to Paul and brought the Gospel of Grace. God will return to the Jews and the Gospel of the Kingdom once this dispensation of Grace has concluded. 

The doctrine of dispensationalism is much more complex than whatever you are working with, whatever was created by divided the bible and picking and choosing what you liked. 

Isaiah has 66 chapters any many if not all correspond to the 66 books. Idk if that can help your disbelief but it was worth trying.

body:
> Ephesians 3:2-13 2 If ye have heard of the dispensation of the grace of God which is given me to you-ward: 3 How that by revelation he made known unto me the mystery; (as I wrote afore in few words, 4 Whereby, when ye read, ye may understand my knowledge in the mystery of Christ) 5 Which in other ages was not made known unto the sons of men, as it is now revealed unto his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit;
> 
> Ephesians 1:10 10 That in the** dispensation of the fulness of times** he might gather together in one all things in Christ, both which are in heaven, and which are on earth; even in him:

οἰκονομία definition: stewardship, administration. This is the problem with using an outdated translation written in very old English which doesn't 100% correspond to modern English. "Unicorn" meant a cow in those days.

> There are 7 Dispensations in the bible. These are two, the Gospel of the Kingdom was what Jesus and John the Baptist preached. The 12 Disciples also preached this to the Jewish remnant or "little flock", those that accepted Jesus as their king prior to the dispensation of Grace. The books of the bible following Philemon intended for Jews during The Great Tribulation or Time of Jacob's Trouble, also are The Gospel of the Kingdom for the Jewish Remnant. God returns to this dispensation after the period of Grace ends. There is also "The Law" which the Jews were under they agreed to at Mt. Sinai, and the instructions Adam and Eve were given. Different ways that God is dealing with humanity during different periods in history.

You won't find a single suggestion of this in the text itself; just in your study notes.

> You can't believe that the sermon on the mound is the same as the gospel of grace, unless you believe you can lose your salvation or that it is conditional upon works:

Sure you can, you just have to realize that people back then were capable of talking like normal people and didn't mean for every syllable they spoke to be interpreted as literally as possible. "In danger" is a neat way of saying what's deserved, it doesn't necessarily mean it's a legal code you're condemned by. "You say we should give murderers the death penalty, but I say that even being angry with someone is deserving of death."

> Romans 11:13 For I speak to you Gentiles, inasmuch as I am the apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine office:

I don't see any definite article before αποστολος in Romans 11:13. Paul does, however, name many other apostles besides himself. Even if Paul did claim that, as faithful as he was clearly had a serious pride problem. According to Paul, you don't just imitate Jesus, you imitate Paul too. It's not only about Jesus's suffering, it's also about Paul's suffering. You disagree with Paul, you are wrong, because Paul is always right. You don't just donate to your faith community, Paul also needs to collect his paycheck. It's not just Christ's gospel, it's Paul's gospel. Paul talks *way* too much about "Me", "Myself", and "I" so such a statement from him wouldn't be completely unexpected, but it's wrong in either case.

Ephesians 3:2-13
2 If ye have heard of the **dispensation of the grace of God** which is given me to you-ward:
3 How that by revelation he made known unto me the mystery; (as I wrote afore in few words,
4 Whereby, when ye read, ye may understand my knowledge in the mystery of Christ)
5 **Which in other ages was not made known unto the sons of men**, as it is now revealed unto his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit;

Ephesians 1:10
10 That in the** dispensation of the fulness of times** he might gather together in one all things in Christ, both which are in heaven, and which are on earth; even in him:

There are 7 Dispensations in the bible. These are two, the Gospel of the Kingdom was what Jesus and John the Baptist preached. The 12 Disciples also preached this to the Jewish remnant or "little flock", those that accepted Jesus as their king prior to the dispensation of Grace. The books of the bible following Philemon intended for Jews during The Great Tribulation or Time of Jacob's Trouble, also are The Gospel of the Kingdom for the Jewish Remnant. God returns to this dispensation after the period of Grace ends. There is also "The Law" which the Jews were under they agreed to at Mt. Sinai, and the instructions Adam and Eve were given. Different ways that God is dealing with humanity during different periods in history. You can't believe that the sermon on the mound is the same as the gospel of grace, unless you believe you can lose your salvation or that it is conditional upon works:

Matthew 5
22 But I say unto you, That whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shall be in danger of the judgment: and whosoever shall say to his brother, Raca, shall be in danger of the council: but whosoever shall say, Thou fool, **shall be in danger of hell fire**.

Under the gospel of Grace we have eternal security in our salvation, dependant solely in our faith that Jesus died for our sins and was resurrected. 

>There is no concept of dispensationalism at all in any bible I'm aware of. That was popularized by Scofield's notes. Paul isn't aware of it either, he preaches the same gospel to both Jews and gentiles.

Yes Paul did preach the same Gospel to Jew and Gentile, because he is preaching during the dispensation of Grace. And I told you "Paul is the apostle to the gentiles and jews during the dispensation of Grace (which we live in)." It's the times before and after Paul's dispensation that are different. Within the dispensation of Grace both Jew and Gentile obtain God's gift of grace the same way, by faith alone. 

Paul is clearly aware that Christians are not under the Jewish law, but under Grace:

Romans 6
14 For sin shall not have dominion over you: for ye are not under the law, but under grace.
15 What then? shall we sin, because we are not under the law, but under grace? God forbid.

And as I quoted above, he was made aware of the dispensation of Grace, which was kept a mystery up until that point. Because Satan would have never killed Christ if he knew what it was going to do and provide to us. At the time he thought getting the Jews to reject Christ and kill him would have gave him a "victory".

>Paul is not "the" apostle to the gentiles, he is only one of them, of which they are many.

Oh yes, Paul is "the" apostle to (of whoops) the gentiles:

Romans 11:13
For I speak to you Gentiles, inasmuch as I am the apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine office:

body:
> It's laughable you try to redefine the word instead of acknowledging what I have said. We can call it the administration of Grace if you prefer. You need to come to terms with the different administrations throughout human history.

You're still twisting the sentence. Paul is talking about *his* administration, aka his evangelist ministry that he was called to do, not eras.

> Again, ignoring what I have said. You are very foolish if you believe people born prior to Christ were justified unto eternal life the same way that I was. You need to study your bible instead of rejecting the parts you don't agree with or can't comprehend.

I have read stories in the old testament and yes, they *were* justified the same way, regardless of what the other parts say which are corrupt according to every reputable prophet. God doesn't change.

> oh ok, the old "this isn't literal" trick when scripture cuts through a flaw in your current understanding.

It's not figurative, but a code of condemnation isn't the idea, it's alluding to the Mosaic law because that's what most of the people watching the speech were accustomed to. The point is "don't be angry with your brother, don't hate your enemies, it's actually worse than you think murder is".

> You accuse Paul of having a pride issue, when it's your own pride that is the issue. You manipulate scripture in all ways I've seen and even disrespect the writer. There is no more to speak to you about.

I'm allowed to call out Paul's mistakes if the intent is to prevent others from being misled. People are also allowed to call out my mistakes, and should. I'm not trying to disrespect Paul, I'm just warning you that he's a bit of a boaster and might think of himself more highly than he actually is.

parent.body:
>οἰκονομία definition: stewardship, administration. This is the problem with using an outdated translation written in very old English which doesn't 100% correspond to modern English. "Unicorn" meant a cow in those days.

It's laughable you try to redefine the word instead of acknowledging what I have said. We can call it the administration of Grace if you prefer. You need to come to terms with the different administrations throughout human history.

>You won't find a single suggestion of this in the text itself; just in your study notes.

Again, ignoring what I have said. You are very foolish if you believe people born prior to Christ were justified unto eternal life the same way that I was. You need to study your bible instead of rejecting the parts you don't agree with or can't comprehend. 

>Sure you can, you just have to realize that people back then were capable of talking like normal people and didn't mean for every syllable they spoke to be interpreted as literally as possible. "In danger" is a neat way of saying what's deserved, it doesn't necessarily mean it's a legal code you're condemned by. "You say we should give murderers the death penalty, but I say that even being angry with someone is deserving of death."

oh ok, the old "this isn't literal" trick when scripture cuts through a flaw in your current understanding.

>I don't see any definite article before αποστολος in Romans 11:13. Paul does, however, name many other apostles besides himself. Even if Paul did claim that, as faithful as he was clearly had a serious pride problem. According to Paul, you don't just imitate Jesus, you imitate Paul too. It's not only about Jesus's suffering, it's also about Paul's suffering. You disagree with Paul, you are wrong, because Paul is always right. You don't just donate to your faith community, Paul also needs to collect his paycheck. It's not just Christ's gospel, it's Paul's gospel. Paul talks way too much about "Me", "Myself", and "I" so such a statement from him wouldn't be completely unexpected, but it's wrong in either case.

Hebrews 4:12
“For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.”

You accuse Paul of having a pride issue, when it's your own pride that is the issue. You manipulate scripture in all ways I've seen and even disrespect the writer. There is no more to speak to you about.

body:
> I saw some people who also have this extreme position, that church is bad, there is nothing good there and only way is to abandon it and go alone.

Nearly every biblical character moved away from organized religion and faced huge conflicts with it. Actually you can make a pretty good argument that it largely contributed to the death of Jesus. Anything that gives humans power is a ripoff to control people.

> It truly is a problem of (not only) today's church that God kinda disappeared from the centre of our lives and it is all just a tradition, a custom to us.

I can't think of any time when God was actually popular. The human race as a whole is hostile to him.

> You can always find, maybe just a little group of people, with whom you can share your spiritual life. Because that is what we do. We have people with whom we share our earthly life, and just like that, we need them for our spiritual life too. And sometimes you just need to hear words from others, because you can not objectively judge yourself, and how bad/good it is with you.

That's not a church, that's a social family.

> And you are wrong that we can not conquer anything from his reign. By yourself, definitely not, you might just get yourself killed. But that's the point of having fellowship with other Christians. Together we can conquer our household/ our school /our work for God. Because we have God on our side.

You underestimate the power of the dark side. Evil always wins here save for a few cases where God directly intervenes. And conquering others is a demonic primal desire in the first place! Why didn't Jesus just cut the crap and destroy Rome so the Pharisees could take over the world already? Because he wasn't here to do that, they just wanted him to because of their superiority fetish which seems to be ingrained in humans. You have no right to complain about the things being done to you if you're just going to turn around and do the same things to them, yet that's how everybody acts. Therefore if you're out to get your opponents, you are really no different from them. And don't start telling yourself, "God is on our side," because he shows no favoritism.
body_html:
I saw some people who also have this extreme position, that church is bad, there is nothing good there and only way is to abandon it and go alone.

Nearly every biblical character moved away from organized religion and faced huge conflicts with it. Actually you can make a pretty good argument that it largely contributed to the death of Jesus. Anything that gives humans power is a ripoff to control people.

It truly is a problem of (not only) today's church that God kinda disappeared from the centre of our lives and it is all just a tradition, a custom to us.

I can't think of any time when God was actually popular. The human race as a whole is hostile to him.

You can always find, maybe just a little group of people, with whom you can share your spiritual life. Because that is what we do. We have people with whom we share our earthly life, and just like that, we need them for our spiritual life too. And sometimes you just need to hear words from others, because you can not objectively judge yourself, and how bad/good it is with you.

That's not a church, that's a social family.

And you are wrong that we can not conquer anything from his reign. By yourself, definitely not, you might just get yourself killed. But that's the point of having fellowship with other Christians. Together we can conquer our household/ our school /our work for God. Because we have God on our side.

You underestimate the power of the dark side. Evil always wins here save for a few cases where God directly intervenes. And conquering others is a demonic primal desire in the first place! Why didn't Jesus just cut the crap and destroy Rome so the Pharisees could take over the world already? Because he wasn't here to do that, they just wanted him to because of their superiority fetish which seems to be ingrained in humans. You have no right to complain about the things being done to you if you're just going to turn around and do the same things to them, yet that's how everybody acts. Therefore if you're out to get your opponents, you are really no different from them. And don't start telling yourself, "God is on our side," because he shows no favoritism.

parent.body:
I saw some people who also have this extreme position, that church is bad, there is nothing good there and only way is to abandon it and go alone. It truly is a problem of (not only) today's church that God kinda disappeared from the centre of our lives and it is all just a tradition, a custom to us. There are churches which abuse people, there are progressive churches that abandoned almost everything that made them Christian. But this can not lead us to abandon it. You can always find, maybe just a little group of people, with whom you can share your spiritual life. Because that is what we do. We have people with whom we share our earthly life, and just like that, we need them for our spiritual life too. And sometimes you just need to hear words from others, because you can not objectively judge yourself, and how bad/good it is with you. 

Devil is the lord of Earth, but definitely not God. And you are wrong that we can not conquer anything from his reign. By yourself, definitely not, you might just get yourself killed. But that's the point of having fellowship with other Christians. Together we can conquer our household/ our school /our work for God. Because we have God on our side.

body: Actually the admins are probably some of the only neurotypicals on the site. And some of their closest discord pals. Probably part of the reason why they fall into a typical clique so easily where they idolize their hierarchy and shit on outsiders, and everyone else gets so annoyed but it prevails regardless. NTs as bad as it is are very accustomed to these kinds of social orders and often cannot see the faults in themselves nor the tribe they've become loyalist to, aka groupthink. This also explains how everyone can fit so neatly into two major parties which are so ideologically inconsistent, because it's more about in-group loyalty than having an actual philosophy. So my guess is that most of the normies are completely fine with and even idolize how sites like reddit are run and only the oddballs end up needing to leave for something less restrictive. Unfortunately we also suck at marketing so the NTs making fake new "free speech" sites that don't stay that way for long always win out.
